Description: Asparagus is a herbaceous perennial plant growing to 100–150 cm (39–59 in) tall with stout stems with much-branched feathery foliage.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Plant as crowns. Best planted at soil temperatures between 61°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 2-3 years. Plant 'crowns' to harvest earlier .
Compatible: Parsley Basil Nasturtiums Lettuce
Soil: A well-drained humus rich soil with added manure/compost. Prefers a loose deep well cultivated and aerated soil.
Maintenance: You should not harvest the spears until three years after planting. In the first two years allow the spears to grow and cut them down to the ground in autumn and make sure that you don't allow it to fruit. In the third season harvest the spears when a good size and make sure that you leave some of the spears behind to photosynthesize and provide the plant with energy to grow the next year.

Description: Ocimum is a genus of aromatic annual and perennial herbs and shrubs in the family Lamiaceae native to the tropical and warm temperate regions of all 6 inhabited continents with the greatest number of species in Africa. Its best known species are the cooking herb cooking basil O. basilicum and the medicinal herb tulsi (holy basil) O. tenuiflorum.
Sowing_Instructions: Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 64°F and 95°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 10-12 weeks. Pick before flowering.
Compatible: Tomato
Soil: Well drained but moist friable and fertile soils. Goes well in a pot on the windowsill where it will deter flies.
Maintenance: Pinch out terminal growth to promote bushiness and prevent going to seed water at midday but don't overdo it as young plants can suffer from damping off

Description: Beta vulgaris (beet) is a plant which is included in Betoideae subfamily in the Amaranthaceae family. It is the economically most important crop of the large order Caryophyllales. It has several cultivar groups: the sugar beet of greatest importance to produce table sugar; the root vegetable known as the beetroot or garden beet; the leaf vegetable known as chard or spinach beet; and mangelwurzel which is a fodder crop.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 45°F and 77°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 7-10 weeks.
Compatible: Onions Silverbeet (Swiss Chard) Lettuce Cabbage Dwarf Beans Dill Peas. Strawberries
Soil: This veggie is not too fussy and it will grow well in any well drained soil with moderate fertility.
Maintenance: Plant at any time except April and May when the roots become about the size of a golf ball lift from the ground.

Description: Broccoli is an edible green plant in the cabbage family whose large flowering head and stalk is eaten as a vegetable. The word broccoli comes from the Italian plural of broccolo which means "the flowering crest of a cabbage" and is the diminutive form of brocco meaning "small nail" or "sprout".
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 45°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 10-16 weeks. Cut flowerhead off with a knife..
Compatible: Dwarf (bush) beans beets celery cucumber onions marigold nasturtium rhubarb aromatic herbs (sage dill chamomile oregano)
Avoid_Instructions: Climbing (pole) beans tomato peppers (chilli capsicum) eggplant (aubergine) strawberry mustard
Soil: Well drained soils that are weed free and slightly limed. They definitely like a fertile soil and reliable moisture.
Maintenance: Water well when hot.

Description: Wild B. oleracea is a tall biennial plant that forms a stout rosette of large leaves in the first year. The leaves are fleshier and thicker than other Brassica species—an adaptation that helps it store water and nutrients in its difficult growing environment. In its second year it uses the stored nutrients to produce a flower spike 1 to 2 metres (3–7 ft) tall with numerous yellow flowers.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 41°F and 64°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 11-15 weeks.
Compatible: Dwarf (bush) beans beets celery cucumber onions marigold nasturtium rhubarb aromatic herbs (sage dill chamomile thyme)
Avoid_Instructions: Climbing (pole) beans tomato peppers (chili capsicum) eggplant (aubergine) strawberry mustard parsnip
Soil: Cabbage needs well drained soils that are weed free and slightly limed.
Maintenance: Water well when hot.

Description: Capsicum annuum is a species of the plant genus Capsicum (peppers). The species encompasses a wide variety of shapes and sizes of peppers both mild and hot such as bell peppers jalapenos New Mexico chile and cayenne peppers. The plant is not an annual but is frost tender.
Sowing_Instructions: Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 64°F and 95°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 10-12 weeks. Cut fruit off with sharp knife.
Compatible: Egg plant (Aubergine) Nasturtiums Basil Parsley Amaranth
Soil: Rich friable soils are best with access to plenty of water in peak growing season.
Maintenance: Liquid feed when flowers appear.

Description: Daucus glochidiatus commonly known as Australian carrot Austral carrot or native carrot is a species of herb in the flowering plant family Apiaceae. It is native to Australia and New Zealand. It grows as an erect annual herb from 2 to 60 centimetres in height but rarely over 20 centimetres. Flowers occur in a range of colours.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 12-18 weeks.
Compatible: Onions Leeks Lettuce Sage Peas Radishes Tomatoes Beans Celery Rosemary
Soil: A deep sandy loam. Remove rocks and stones as they will encourage deformities.
Maintenance: You can sow these anytime except Autumn. Plant 25cm apart and compact the soil around the seed. Make sure it stays well watered. Fertilise twice when growing. Carrots generally need around 4 months from planting to harvest.

Description: Cauliflower is one of several vegetables in the species Brassica oleracea in the genus Brassica which is in the family Brassicaceae. It is an annual plant that reproduces by seed. Brassica oleracea also includes broccoli brussels sprouts cabbage collard greens and kale collectively called "cole" crops though they are of different cultivar groups.
Sowing_Instructions: Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 15-22 weeks.
Compatible: Dwarf (bush) beans beets celery cucumber onions marigold nasturtium rhubarb aromatic herbs (sage dill chamomile)
Avoid_Instructions: Climbing (pole) beans tomato peppers (chili capsicum) eggplant (aubergine) strawberry mustard
Soil: Well drained soils that are weed free and slightly limed. They like a fertile soil and reliable moisture.
Maintenance: Water well when hot in late summer as they develop and apply a nitrogen based fertiliser when they are around 0.3m high. Keep weed free but don't disturb the roots. Remove lower leaves as the rosettes develop and tie the closer ones up over the crown to keep it white and tender before harvesting.

Description: Celery (Apium graveolens) is a marshland plant in the family Apiaceae that has been cultivated as a vegetable since antiquity. Celery has a long fibrous stalk tapering into leaves. Depending on location and cultivar either its stalks leaves or hypocotyl are eaten and used in cooking. Celery seed is also used as a spice and its extracts have been used in herbal medicine.
Sowing_Instructions: Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 54°F and 70°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 17-18 weeks.
Compatible: Not applicable as celery needs to be close together to encourage blanching.
Soil: A light well drained soil with plenty of added humus. Slightly frost hardy.
Maintenance: Sow directly into the ground as they are difficult to transplant.

Description: Coriandrum sativum also known as Coriandrum sativum the stems and leaves of which are usually called is an annual herb in the family Apiaceae. All parts of the plant are edible but the fresh leaves and the dried seeds (as a spice) are the parts most traditionally used in cooking.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50°F and 77°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 30-45 days.
Compatible: Dill Chervil Anise Cabbages Carrots
Soil: It needs a light soil with reasonable fertility and very good drainage. A sunny location is good though in high summer it will bolt to seed if too hot so some summer dappled shade will be helpful.
Maintenance: Trim the leaves as needed and remove the seeds when they start to turn brown. Cutting off the flower heads before they turn to seed will create more leaves to harvest.

Description: Cucumber (Cucumis sativus) is a widely cultivated plant in the gourd family Cucurbitaceae. It is a creeping vine that bears cucumiform fruits that are used as vegetables.
Sowing_Instructions: Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 61°F and 95°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 8-10 weeks. Cut fruit off with scissors or sharp knife.
Compatible: Nasturtiums Beans Celery Lettuce Sweet Corn Cabbages Sunflowers Coriander Fennel Dill Sunflowers
Soil: It needs a rich moist soil with good drainage. Mix plenty of organic matter into the soil before planting and it's also a good idea to mulch the soil with compost or a straw mulch to keep the moisture in the soil. Space 45 cms apart and allow 7-10 weeks to reach maturity.
Maintenance: They need to be trained onto a trellis or other support or the fruits will rot if in contact with the soil. Remove the fruits as soon as they are a good size and this will encourage further fruit production.

Description: Eggplant is a plant species in the nightshade family Solanaceae Solanum melongena grown for its often purple edible fruit. The eggplant is a delicate tropical perennial plant often cultivated as a tender or half-hardy annual in temperate climates. The stem is often spiny.
Sowing_Instructions: Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 75°F and 90°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 12-15 weeks. Cut fruit with scissors or sharp knife.
Compatible: Beans capsicum lettuce amaranth thyme
Soil: It can tolerate most soils with adequate drainage and reliable moisture. Keep well watered in warm weather. if soils are sandy. Feed with potassium rich fertilisers when fruits are swelling.
Maintenance: Train it to a single stem at first and when it's about 0.3m tall pinch out the terminal growth bud to encourage side branching. Limit each plant to 6-8 fruits to maximise size. The fruits are ready to harvest when they give slightly when touched but are still firm.

Description: Allium ampeloprasum is a member of the onion genus Allium. The wild plant is commonly known as wild leek or broadleaf wild leek.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 15-18 weeks. Loosen with a fork rather than pull by hand..
Compatible: Carrots
Soil: Well drained fertile weed free soils with plenty of compost or manure added - leeks prefer a cooler climate. Best sown in seed trays and pricked out to larger trays then planted out once hardened.
Maintenance: Keep well watered and fertilised - their growth rate slows dramtically in autumn so you can harvest them over a longer period than other veggies. Once harvested they can be stored for up to 2-3 months if kept quite cool and in humid conditions.

Description: Lactuca sativa is a member of the Lactuca (lettuce) genus and the Asteraceae (sunflower or aster) family. Lettuce (Lactuca sativa) is an annual plant of the daisy family Asteraceae. It is most often grown as a leaf vegetable but sometimes for its stem and seeds. Lettuce is most often used for salads.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden or start in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks.. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 8°C and 27°C. (Show °F/in)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 8-12 weeks.
Compatible: Carrots Onions Strawberries Beets Brassicas Radish Marigold Borage Chervil Florence fennel leeks.
Soil: Light well drained and fertile soils with some added organic matter to retain moisture.
Maintenance: Shade young plants in the hottest weather keep well watered to ensure crisp leaves. A light liquid feed will help promote strong growth

Description: The onion (Allium cepa L. from Latin cepa "onion") also known as the bulb onion or common onion is a vegetable that is the most widely cultivated species of the genus Allium. Its close relatives include the garlic leek chive and Chinese onion. The onion is most frequently a biennial or a perennial plant but is usually treated as an annual and harvested in its first growing season.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 25-34 weeks. Allow onions to dry before storing.
Compatible: Lemon Balm Borage Carrots Beets Silverbeet Lettuce Amaranth
Soil: Well drained fertile weed free soils. Ensure they are planted far enough apart for a good clearance between the final sized bodies.
Maintenance: Let foliage die back after flowering. Onions store well but it is a good idea to harvest as needed as they will not rot initially.

Description: Parsley or garden parsley (Petroselinum crispum) is a species of flowering plant in the family Apiaceae. it grows as a biennial in the first year it forms a rosette of tripinnate leaves 10–25 cm (3.9–9.8 in) long with numerous 1–3 cm (0.4–1.2 in) leaflets and a taproot used as a food store over the winter. In the second year it grows a flowering stem with sparser leaves and umbels with yellow to yellowish-green flowers.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 9-19 weeks. Cut stalks from outer part of plant.
Compatible: Carrots Chives Tomatoes Asparagus
Soil: A good quality potting mix or any well drained soil that has some composted materials added to keep miosture available without waterlogging.
Maintenance: Regular harvesting of small quantities by hand should be enough to keep it in good shape otherwise keep watered in hot weather.

Description: The parsnip (Pastinaca sativa) is a root vegetable closely related to carrot and parsley; all belong to the family Apiaceae. It is a biennial plant usually grown as an annual. Its long tuberous root has cream-colored skin and flesh and left in the ground to mature it becomes sweeter in flavor after winter frosts. In its first growing season the plant has a rosette of pinnate mid-green leaves.
Sowing_Instructions: Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 43°F and 70°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 17-20 weeks. Best flavour if harvested after a frost..
Compatible: Swiss Chard (Silverbeet) Capsicum Peas Potatoes Beans Radishes Garlic
Soil: Best in deep sandy stone free soils to encourage smooth shaped roots. Do not plant close to Brassicas celery or carrots.
Maintenance: Keep well watered over hot summers.

Description: The pea is most commonly the small spherical seed or the seed-pod of the pod fruit Pisum sativum. P. sativum is an annual plant with a life cycle of one year. It is a cool-season crop grown in many parts of the world; planting can take place from winter to early summer depending on location. The average pea weighs between 0.1 and 0.36 gram.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 8°C and 24°C. (Show °F/in)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 9-11 weeks. Pick the pods every day to increase production.
Compatible: Potatoes
Soil: A fertile soil with added organic matter and reliable moisture. They also like it on the Alkaline side so check the pH and add some garden lime or dolomite if needed.
Maintenance: Peas are climbers so it'll be necessary to provide a support with some stakes and wire or twigs. Harvest the peas early while they are most flavoursome.

Description: Potato plants are herbaceous perennials that grow about 60 cm (24 in) high depending on variety with the leaves dying back after flowering fruiting and tuber formation. They bear white pink red blue or purple flowers with yellow stamens. In general the tubers of varieties with white flowers have white skins while those of varieties with colored flowers tend to have pinkish skins.[20] Potatoes are mostly cross-pollinated by insects such as bumblebees which carry pollen from other potato plants though a substantial amount of self-fertilizing occurs as well.
Sowing_Instructions: Plant tuber. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 15-20 weeks. Dig carefully avoid damaging the potatoes.
Compatible: Peas Beans Brassicas Sweetcorn Broad Beans Nasturtiums Marigolds
Soil: Open and well drained friable soils - best planted in raised rows and mulched with straw in cold climates.
Maintenance: Keep well watered especially during high growth phases - but don't let them become waterlogged or the potato tubers will rot.

Description: Cucurbita (Latin for gourd) is a genus of herbaceous vines in the gourd family Cucurbitaceae also known as cucurbits native to the Andes and Mesoamerica. Most Cucurbita species are herbaceous vines that grow several meters in length and have tendrils but non-vining "bush". The fruits of the genus Cucurbita are good sources of nutrients such as vitamin A and vitamin C among other nutrients according to species.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 68°F and 90°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 15-20 weeks.
Compatible: Sweet Corn
Soil: Moist soils enrichened with plenty of organic matter. Best planted on a mound of soil to encourage drainage.
Maintenance: Kabocha are harvested while the fruits are still growing meaning that they will continue to ripen. keep them in a warm place for two weeks to allow the starches to convert to carbohydrates. then keep them in a cool place for up to three months where they will develop their distinctive sweeter flavour and yellowy to red flesh

Description: Raphanus raphanistrum (the wild radish white charlock or jointed charlock) is a flowering plant in the family Brassicaceae. It is sometimes claimed to be the ancestor of the edible radish Raphanus sativus. It has been introduced into most parts of the world and is regarded as a habitat threatening invasive species in many areas for example Australia. It spreads rapidly and is often found growing on roadsides or in other places where the ground has been disturbed.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 46°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 5-7 weeks.
Compatible: Chervil cresslettuce leeks spinach strawberries tomatoes
Soil: Radishes are very adaptable but prefer a fertile aerated soil with good drainage and reliable moisture. Cultivate the soil well before planting out.
Maintenance: Seeds should be sown 1cm deep and 2cm apart with a 30cm space between rows. When the leaves appear it's a good idea to thin them out or the radishes will be stunted. Harvest about 4 weeks after sowing and you can leave some behind to set seed. To ensure best flavour and crispness always keep then well watered which makes them grow quickly. One day without water means they slow their growth rate and loose their flavour.

Description: Rhubarb is grown widely and with greenhouse production it is available throughout much of the year. Rhubarb grown in hothouses (heated greenhouses) is called "hothouse rhubarb" and is typically made available at consumer markets in early spring before outdoor cultivated rhubarb is available. Hothouse rhubarb is usually brighter red tenderer and sweeter-tasting than outdoor rhubarb.[6] In temperate climates rhubarb is one of the first food plants harvested usually in mid- to late spring.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Plant pieces of rhizome or roots 8 - 10 cm (3 - 4 in.) deep. Best planted at soil temperatures between 41°F and 68°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in approximately 1 years. You will have a stronger plant if you leave it for about a year before using..
Compatible: Brassicas (Cabbage Broccoli Cauliflower etc)
Soil: It likes a well drained friable soil that is rich with organic matter. Space plants 1.0-1.5 metres apart in order to maximise cropping. Keep it well watered though and a straw mulch will help maintain that moisture while keeping weeds at bay.
Maintenance: Dig in good quantities of compost or composted manures in autumn. N.B. do not use fresh manure as it will burn the plant. Propogate by dividing the rhizomes in winter.

Description: Eruca vesicaria (syn. Brassica vesicaria L.) also known as arugula rocket and rocket salad is a species of Eruca. It is an annual plant growing to 20–100 cm tall. The leaves are deeply pinnately lobed with four to ten small lateral lobes and a large terminal lobe. The flowers are 2–4 cm diameter arranged in a corymb with the typical Brassicaceae flower structure; the petals are creamy white with purple veins and the stamens yellow; the sepals are persistent after the flower opens.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50°F and 77°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 21-35 days.
Compatible: Lettuce
Soil: Plant seedlings 15-20 cms apart in fertile well drained soil and firm down. Keep well watered until established
Maintenance: Harvest by cutting off leaves as required and they will produce for you for many weeks though thev will become stronger in taste as they age. In which case keep new ones coming planting out every three to four weeks.

Description: Silverbeet is also known as chard Swiss chard and seakale beet. It is similar to spinach but has a stronger flavour. Silverbeet usually has a white stalk however red beet is sometimes available; it has the same green leaves but has a rich pink-red stem and veins.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50°F and 86°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 7-12 weeks.
Compatible: Beans brassica sp. (cabbage cauliflower etc) tomato allium sp. (onion garlic chives) lavender parsnip
Avoid_Instructions: Corn melon cucurbit (cucumbers squash melons gourds) most herbs potato.
Soil: This vegie is not too picky and it will grow well in any well drained soil with moderate fertility.
Maintenance: Plant at all year round and keep well watered when in full growth.

Description: Spinach is an annual plant (rarely biennial) growing as tall as 30 cm (1 ft). Spinach may overwinter in temperate regions. The leaves are alternate simple ovate to triangular and very variable in size: 2–30 cm (1–12 in) long and 1–15 cm (0.4–5.9 in) broad with larger leaves at the base of the plant and small leaves higher on the flowering stem. The flowers are inconspicuous yellow-green 3–4 mm (0.1–0.2 in) in diameter and mature into a small hard dry lumpy fruit cluster 5–10 mm (0.2–0.4 in) across containing several seeds.
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50°F and 77°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 5-11 weeks.
Compatible: Broad beans (fava) cabbage cauliflower celery eggplant (aubergine) onion peas strawberry santolina
Soil: A deep fertile soil with good drainage. Spinach needs reliable moisture to prevent it from setting seed.
Maintenance: Plant in well-cultivated soil at 25cm intervals.

Description: The spring onion with its vivid green stem has long been a favourite to add a dash of colour to stir-fried dishes. The vegetable also gives a delicate onion flavour and crunch when eaten raw in salads sandwiches and salsas. Spring onions are an excellent source of vitamin C and calcium. They are also a good source of dietary fibre and vitamins A and B6 thiamine folate and minerals (potassium copper chromium manganese iron).
Sowing_Instructions: Easy to grow. Sow in garden. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 50°F and 68°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 8-12 weeks.
Compatible: Lemon Balm Borage Carrots Beets Silverbeet Lettuce Amaranth
Soil: Well drained fertile weed free soils
Maintenance: Onion fly stem eelworm onion white rot.

Description: Thymus vulgaris (common thyme German thyme garden thyme or just thyme) is a species of flowering plant in the mint family Lamiaceae native to southern Europe from the western Mediterranean to southern Italy. Growing to 15–30 cm (6–12 in) tall by 40 cm (16 in) wide it is a bushy woody-based evergreen subshrub with small highly aromatic grey-green leaves and clusters of purple or pink flowers in early summer.
Sowing_Instructions: Grow in seed trays and plant out 6-8 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 59°F and 77°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 42-52 weeks. Root divisions ready in 3 months.
Compatible: Dry-environment herbs (oreganosage) Eggplant Cabbage
Soil: Moist well drained soil.
Maintenance: Remove flower heads after flowering to produce rich dense foliage. Renew the plant every two to three years - unless it has self seeded.

Description: Tomato plants are vines initially decumbent typically growing 180 cm (6 ft) or more above the ground if supported although erect bush varieties have been bred generally 100 cm (3 ft) tall or shorter. Indeterminate types are "tender" perennials dying annually in temperate climates (they are originally native to tropical highlands) although they can live up to three years in a greenhouse in some cases.
Sowing_Instructions: Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 61°F and 95°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 8-17 weeks.
Compatible: Asparagus ChervilCarrot Celery Chives Parsley Marigold Basil
Soil: Fertile well drained and warm soils. Don't plant tomatoes in the same soil two years in a row to avoid disease carry-over. Add a sprinkle of lime - as toms like calcium.
Maintenance: Grow from seeds or buy seedlings - however keep both protected until they are established (30cms tall at least) before planting out with stakes to hold them up. Some will grow prostrate but become prone to slugs. Keep moist but don't overwater feed often during growing phases with a fertiliser formulated specially for tomatoes.

Description: The zucchini is a summer squash which can reach nearly 1 metre (100 cm; 39 in) in length but is usually harvested when still immature at about 15 to 25 cm (6 to 10 in). When used for food zucchini are usually picked when under 20 cm (8 in) in length when the seeds are still soft and immature. Mature zucchini can be a metre long or more. The larger ones are often fibrous. A zucchini with the flowers attached is a sign of a truly fresh and immature fruit and it is especially sought after for its sweeter flavor.
Sowing_Instructions: Grow in seed trays and plant out in 4-6 weeks. Sow seed at a depth approximately three times the diameter of the seed. Best planted at soil temperatures between 70°F and 95°F. (Show °C/cm)
harvestInstructions: Harvest in 6-9 weeks. Cut the fruit often to keep producing.
Compatible: Corn beans nasturtiums parsley Silverbeet Tomatoes
Soil: Moist soils enrichened with plenty of organic matter. Best planted on a mound of soil to encourage drainage.
Maintenance: Apply a balance fertiliser when the flowers come into bud. Plant 2.5cm deep and harvest continually to prolong fruiting. N.B. It's best not to water the leaves as this promotes mildew.
